MRIintro.text: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is a non-invasive technique that uses strong magnets and radio waves to see organs and tissues inside the body. In the field of neuroscience researchers use MRI to gather images of subjects' brains. This is called neuroimaging.
3D images of the brain are examined one slice at a time resulting in a series of 2D images for every scan.
Researchers gather images while the subject is at rest or while performing a task.
Images gathered at rest are used to study the shape, size, organization and composition of the subject's brain. These images are called structural images or anatomical images.

Images gathered while performing a task are used to study how the subject used their brain during that task. These images are called functional images. Techniques that gather these images are called Functional MRI or fMRI.

The most widely used type of structural image is the T1-weighted image (T1). T1 images show the difference between gray matter and white matter in the brain. In T1 images of adult brains, white matter appears white and gray matter appears gray.

Another commonly used type of structural image is the T2-weighted image (T2). T2 images highlight the brain differently than T1 images. In T2 images of adult brains, white matter appears darker than gray matter.

The primary type of functional image is a Blood Oxygen Level Dependent signal image or BOLD image. These images show the change in oxygen levels in the brain's blood over time. In isolation, functional images appear blurry.

After gathering MRI images they are processed by a supercomputer. This makes it possible to accurately map a subject's brain and compare images to one another. One image can be compared to another type of image from the same subject, and to the images of any other subject.
To help researchers map the structure of the cortical surface, the supercomputer draws lines to seperate gray matter and white matter. This is called surface delineation.
To help researchers compare an image to other images of the same subject the supercomputer overlays one image on the other. This is called co-registration.

To help researchers compare one subject's images to another subject's images the supercomputer slightly reshapes them and compares them and their surface delineations to a standardized map of the brain. This standardized map is called an atlas. Comparing an image to an atlas in this way is called atlas registration.

QAintro.text: Ideally all images that are gathered via MRI and processed by a supercomputer can be used for analyses. However, some images are low quality and using them in analysis would generate poor results.

Researchers have a standard set of metrics to determine whether the images are high enough quality to be used in analysis. The act of assesing the level of an image's quality is called Quality Assessment (QA).

Though automated tools are being developed, the best way to perform QA is manually. This is a difficult task for datasets that include thousands of subjects. This task becomes acheivable when it is shared between many people.
We welcome you to BrainSwipes, a central platform for neuroimaging datasets that need quality assessment. Below you will learn how to perform QA on processed images of the brain acquired through MRI.

QAimagetypes.text: You will be performing QA on 3 categories of images. Surface delineations of anatomical images, atlas registrations and functional registrations.
You will perform QA on individual T1 and T2 slices to determine the quality of their surface delineations.

There are 3 standard angles used when researchers examine the brain. Image slices from each angle fall into a plane, the Coronal plane, Axial plane or Sagittal plane. The coronal plane is the plane seen when looking at a persons face or the back of their head. The axial plane is the plane seen looking at the top of their head. The sagittal plane is the plane seen looking at the sides of their head. Surface delineation is performed on all of these slices.
Here is an example of how an individual, delineated T1 slice will look in the app.
Here is an example of how an individual, delineated T2 slice will look in the app.
You will perform QA on 9 slices of the same T1 to determine the quality of its registration to an atlas.

Atlas registration on structural data is done in two ways. A T1 can be overlayed onto an atlas or an atlas can be overlayed onto a T1. For whichever way this is done, surface delineations of the first image are drawn over the second image.
Here is an example of how a T1 registered to an atlas will look in the app.
Here is an example of how an atlas registered to a T1 will look in the app. A registration of an atlas onto a T1 will have heavy red lines in the center sagittal slice.
You will perform QA on 9 slices of the same functional image to determine the quality of its registration to a T1.

Functional Registration to a T1 is done in two ways. A functional image can be overlayed onto a structural image or structural image can be overlayed onto a functional image. For whichever way this is done, surface delineations of the first image are drawn over the second image.

Here is an example of how a functional image registered to a T1 will look in the app. A functional image registered to a T1 will have sparse or dotted red lines because functional images are blurrier leading to the supercomputer drawing less delineations.
Here is an example of how a T1 registered to a functional image will look in the app. A T1 registered to a functional image will have a blurry background image because functional images are blurry.

structuralQA.text: Assessing the Quality of Surface Delineations

A quality surface delineation will accurately delineate the cortical surface. White matter will be seperated from gray matter with a gray line. Gray matter will be seperated from the surrounding fluid with a red line. Each colored line will capture only one type of tissue.

Ignore the subcortical regions highlighted between the temporal lobes in the coronal view. 
Surface delineation is only concerned with the outer area of the brain called the cortex.
Blurriness occurs when the participant is moving in the scanner and can make it difficult to delineate the surface.
Blurriness in the T1 does not always make the surface delineation bad quality.

Ringing occurs when the participant is moving in the scanner and can disrupt the surface delineation 
because the rings can be mistaken as brain or make the brain unrecognizable.
Ringing in the T1 does not always make the surface delineation bad quality.
White matter extension is when the white matter is poorly delineated and extends to the gray matter line.

Another error is when the surface delineation goes outside of the brain and into the dura or skull. 
The dura is the faint gray line between the brain and the skull. The skull is the thick white line.
The image is also bad quality when the white and gray matter surface delineations cross over each other.

Warps of the brain, skull, and surface delineations are caused by poor atlas registration. 
These warps appear to 'pull' the brain and surface delineations.
Below are examples of good and bad quality surface delineation:

A quality atlas registration will correctly and accurately register an atlas to a T1 or a T1 to an atlas. All overlayed delineations will match the gray and white matter below. The boundaries of the underlying image will be the same size as the overlay, with no excess black space and no delineations that do not capture the whole underlying image.

The quality of the atlas registration depends on how well the T1 aligns to the boundaries of the MNI atlas.
The goal is to have all participants’ overlaid images look the same so their brain shapes are the same and can be compared.
The T1 may not align to the atlas due to not extending to the atlas boundaries.
However if the T1 is minimally inside the atlas boundaries it is not necessarily bad quality.
The T1 may also extend outside of the atlas boundaries.
However if the T1 extends minimally outside of the atlas boundaries it is not necessarily bad quality.

functionalQA.text: Assesing the Quality of Functional Registration

The quality of the fMRI registration depends on how well the fMRI image and T1 align. 
Common functional registration errors include: 
field of view cut off and signal dropout.

Field of view cut-off occurs when the participant’s head is not fully in the image field of view and 
either the bottom or top of the brain appears cut off.

Not all field of view cut-off errors imply bad quality, 
it is more important to what extent the brain is cut off.

In this flipped example, which depicts the functional image as a greyscale image with the anatomical as a red overlaid trace, the functional image has some cutoff in the cerebellum. 
However, because the temporal lobe is minimally cutoff, the image would still be considered a PASS.

Signal dropout occurs where the scanner cannot acquire data during a scan. 
There are many reasons this can occur.

Not all signal dropout errors imply bad quality, 
it is more important to what extent the signal is not recorded.

Ignore movement artifacts when assessing the quality of the functional registration. 
Movement artifacts occur when the participant is moving too much during the fMRI scan but still is a PASS if the T1 and fMRI align well.

Ignore warped brain shapes when assessing the quality of the functional registration. 
Warped brains are due to poor registration of the T1 to the MNI atlas and are not a problem with the functional scan.
Below are examples of good and bad quality fMRI scans:

examples.text:
Swipe right when the image is good quality.
 The gray matter and white matter is properly delineated.

Swipe left when its bad:
 Too much white matter cut off
Swipe right: Only minor gray matter cutoff around the perimeter of the brain.
Swipe right: Functional registration passes with only minor cutoff in functional data.

Swipe left:
 Large areas where functional data is not registered to the atlas.

if you're not sure, click 'help' 
 to discuss with scientists
Thank you for helping perform QA on neuroimaging datasets. Every swipe helps!
